facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 80 of 1972 is an appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated January 23, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 392 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL, APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 80 of 1972. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated January 23, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 392 of 1970.

facts.text: The appellant is the owner of 32, Balrampur House, Mumfordganj, Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the owner of 32, Balrampur House, Mumfordganj, Allahabad.

facts.text: The appellant let out his house on September 9, 1964 to the State Government for a period of 5 years on a monthly rent of Rs. 300/- for the purposes of residence or Office of the Directorate of Geology and Mining, U.P.

anchor.surface_text: After residing therein for some time, he started living in 33 Pan Dariba, Allahabad with his mother. His own house he let out on September 9, 1964 to the State Government for a period of 5 years- on a I monthly rent of Rs. 300/-. The State Government obtained the lease for the purposes of residence or Office of the Directorate of Geology and Mining, U.P.

facts.text: The lease was signed by Shri P. N. Singh, Geologist, on behalf of the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The lease was signed by Shri P. N. Singh, Geologist, on behalf of the State Government.

facts.text: In 1967 the appellant shifted from house No. 33, Pan Dariba to house No. 39,8/5, Meerapur, Allahabad where he was living as a tenant.

anchor.surface_text: In 1967 the appellant had shifted from the house No. 33, Pan Dariba to house No. 39,8/5, Meerapur, Allahabad. In Meerapur he was living as a tenant.

facts.text: The period of lease with respect to his own house expired on September 9, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The period of lease with respect to Ms own house expired on September 9, 1969.

facts.text: The District Magistrate, Allahabad passed an order under S. 3 of the U.P. Temporary Accommodation Requisition Act, 1947 on October 4, 1969 requisitioning the house to provide accommodation to Shri P. N. Singh, Geologist, Directorate of Geology and Mining, U.P.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, Allahabad passed an order under S. 3 of the U.P.  Temporary  Accommodation Requisition Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The order was made on October 4, 1969. By the order the District Magistrate requisitioned the house to provide accommodation to Shri P. N. Singh, Geologist, Directorate of Geology and Mining, U.P.

facts.text: The appellant was directed to hand over possession of the house within 24 hours after the expiry of 15 days from the date of the service of the order on him.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was directed to hand over possession of the house within 24 hours after the expiry of 15 days from the date of the service of the order on him.

facts.text: The appellant filed a writ petition in the Allahabad High Court challenging the validity of the order, one ground being that the order was made without issuing any notice to him and without giving him a hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a writ petition in the Allahabad High Court challenging the validity of the order. One of the grounds of challenge was that the order was made without issuing any numberice to him and without giving him a hearing.

facts.text: The writ petition was dismissed summarily by a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed summarily by a Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: The High Court did not accept the argument of want of notice and hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The argument of want of numberice and hearing was number accepted by the High Court.

facts.text: The appellant filed this appeal by special leave feeling aggrieved with the decision of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved with the decision of the High Court, the appellant has filed this appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Counsel for the District Magistrate argued that the court should not entertain the argument as it was not raised before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the District Magistrate says that we should number entertain the argument as it was number raised before the High Court.

facts.text: The Supreme Court found that the point of want of notice was raised before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: But we are satisfied on a reading of the judgment of the High Court that the point was raised by the appellant before the High Court. Rejecting the argument, the High Court said Where a person is being deprived of his property...

facts.text: The requisitioning order was made without notice and hearing to the appellant, which is not disputed by the District Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed on behalf of the District Magistrate that the requisitioning order was made by him without giving numberice and hearing to the appellant.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the order of requisition is invalid for want of notice and hearing.

anchor.surface_text: So we hold that his order is illegal. The appeal is allowed with companyts.

facts.text: The High Court rejected the argument stating that requisition is temporary and detailed procedure is not necessary.

anchor.surface_text: Where a person is being deprived of his property, it can be said that he should be given an opportunity before the land is acquired but by requisition the property is taken away from his use for a temporary period and for such requisition such a detailed procedure is number necessary.

facts.text: Section 3 of the Act does not expressly provide for notice and hearing before the requisitioning order.

anchor.surface_text: Evidently it does number companytain an express provision for numberice and hearing before the making of the requisitioning order.

facts.text: The Act has remained on the statute book for 25 years.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Act is a temporary measure, but it has remained on the statute book for 25 years.

facts.text: There is acute scarcity of accommodation in the State.

anchor.surface_text: There is acute scarcity of accommodation in the State, and an accommodation once requisitioned is ordinarily number expected to be restored early to the owner.

facts.text: The appeal is allowed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed with companyts.
Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 392 of 1970.
Feeling aggrieved with the decision of the High Court, the appellant has filed this appeal by special leave.

The District Magistrate, Allahabad passed an order under S. 3 of the U.P. Temporary Accommodation Requisition Act, 1947 hereinafter referred to as the Act . The order was made on October 4, 1969. By the order the District Magistrate requisitioned the house to provide accommodation to Shri P. N. Singh, Geologist, Directorate of Geology and Mining, U.P.

issues.text: whether the requisitioning order is invalid for want of notice and hearing

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved with the decision of the High Court, the appellant has filed this appeal by special leave. Counsel for the appellant has submitted before us that the requisitioning order is invalid for want of notice and hearing.

issues.text: whether the court should not entertain the argument as it was not raised before the High Court

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the District Magistrate says that we should not entertain the argument as it was not raised before the High Court. But we are satisfied on a reading of the judgment of the High Court that the point was raised by the appellant before the High Court.

issues.text: whether s. 3 of the Act can be said to be ultra vires simply because it does not provide for a show cause notice

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the order of requisition is not invalid, nor can s. 3 of the Act be said to be ultra vires simply because it does not provide for a show cause notice

issues.text: whether s. 3 contains a provision for notice and hearing by necessary implication

anchor.surface_text: Evidently it does not contain an express provision for notice and hearing before the making of the requisitioning order. But it appears to us that such a provision is to be read therein by necessary implication. The object of the provision is to requisition an immovable property.

issues.text: whether principles of natural justice requiring notice and hearing apply to the administrative act of the District Magistrate under s. 3

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the District Magistrate has submitted that the District Magistrate acts in an administrative capacity under s. 3. According to him, it is not necessary to hear the affected party in an administrative proceeding. He has relied on Province of Bombay v. Bhanji Munji and another the principles of natural justice would not apply to the administrative act of selection of officers for appointment to the Indian Forest Service.

arguments.claim: principles of natural justice apply to administrative actions affecting rights as per Kraipak, Daud Ahmad and Erry

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant has relied on A. K. Kraipak and others v. Union of India, Daud Ahmad v. The District Magistrate, Allahabad and others and State of Punjab v. R. Erry and Sobhag Rai Mehta.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nt the law of the land but supplement it. If the purpose of the rules of natural justice is to prevent miscarriage one fails to see why those rules sh

arguments.court_reasoning: supports implication of notice and hearing in s.3; Daud Ahmad directly on point under same Act

arguments.claim: precedents like Bhanji Munji and Collector of Akola do not apply as issue of notice and hearing did not directly arise

anchor.surface_text: In none of these cases the issue of notice and hearing directly arose for consideration.

arguments.claim: first proviso to s.3 implies notice and hearing as it raises factual dispute on religious use

anchor.surface_text: The first proviso to s. 3 provides that no building or part of a building exclusively used for religious worship shall be requisitioned by the District Magistrate. Whether a building or part of a building is being exclusively used for religious worship, is a question of fact.

arguments.claim: second proviso to s.3 implies notice and hearing on issue of actual occupation and alternative accommodation

anchor.surface_text: The second proviso also seems to support that inference. It provides that no accommodation which is in the actual occupation of any person shall be requisitioned unless the District Magistrate is of opinion that suitable alternative accommodation exists for his needs or has been provided to him.

arguments.claim: no appeal or revision from DM order under s.3 so plenary authority requires notice and hearing to avoid unfairness

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to bear in mind that the Act does not provide for any appeal or revision from the order of the District Magistrate under s. 3. The District Magistrate is constituted the plenary authority

holdings.text: we are satisfied on a reading of the judgment of the High Court that the point was raised by the appellant before the High Court

anchor.surface_text: But we are satisfied on a reading of the judgment of the High Court that the point was raised by the appellant before the High Court. Rejecting the argument, the High Court said Where a person is being deprived of his property, it can be said that he should be given an opportunity before the land is acquired but by requisition the property is taken away from his use for a temporary period and for such requisition such a detailed procedure is number necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of High Court judgment confirms the argument of want of notice was raised and rejected

holdings.text: the order of requisition is not invalid, nor can s. 3 of the Act be said to be ultra vires simply because it does not provide for a show cause notice

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the order of requisition is number invalid, number can s. 3 of the Act be said to be ultra vires simply because it does number provide for a show cause numberice to be served on the owner before the order of requisition can be passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of express provision for notice does not invalidate the section or order outright, as implication possible

holdings.text: such a provision [for notice and hearing] is to be read [in s. 3] by necessary implication

anchor.surface_text: Evidently it does number companytain an express provision for numberice and hearing before the making of the requisitioning order. But it appears to us that such a provision is to be read therein by necessary implication. The object of the provision is to requisition an immovable property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Object of requisitioning depriving property right, provisos raising factual issues, absence of appeal, scheme require hearing for fairness

holdings.text: the scheme and setting of s. 3 imply a notice and hearing to the person who will be affected by the proposed requisitioning order

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disposed of the point without examining the scheme and setting of s. 3. In our view the scheme and setting of s. 3 imply a numberice and hearing to the person who will be affected by the proposed requisitioning order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrative action affecting property rights requires natural justice per evolving doctrine; precedents like Kraipak, Daud Ahmad apply; distinction from prior cases

anchor.surface_text: So we hold that his order is illegal. The appeal is allowed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed absence of notice and hearing violates implied mandatory requirement under s. 3
